title: How to Make a Video Game Level

steps.headline: First off decide upon what kind of game you're making.
Always make each level center around a single theme.
When it comes to music think what would fit best.
steps.description: The Banjo-Kazooie series is ground-breaking in this regard since every level's music sounds exactly as it should. The level that consists of a polluted harbor is quirky and low-pitched whilst the level that consists of the 4 seasons each has a different music for each season: a cheery, chirpy song  for spring, a slow violin tune for summer, an upbeat horn tune for fall and a harp-like tune with tambourines for winter.

steps.headline: If you wish to have a boss have the boss fit with the theme of said level.
steps.description: If the level is themed to the Amazon rainforest have a tapir or sloth be the boss. Make sure that under any conditions you don't interchange it (e.g. in a water-themed level you have a desert lizard boss).

steps.headline: How difficult it is should depend on how early and/or later in the game it is.
If possible try to think up of a theme that has never been done before.
steps.description: Once more the Banjo-Kazooie series is a good example of this. For example beforehand no one had ever tried to make levels like a cargo-loading polluted harbor, the Mesozoic Era, or a forest in the four seasons of the year. Try to think outside the box.

steps.headline: The kind of challenges should once again depend on the level's theme.
steps.description: If the level is wind-themed perhaps you need to get something out of a cloud without being set afire away by a strong wind.

text:
First off decide upon what kind of game you're making. If it's a non-linear, explore-everything game like Banjo-Kazooie or Legend of Zelda then every level should be a different theme and be very spread out. If it's a linear war game like Halo or Call of Duty make it a campaign and each level is in a predesignated order. If it's the latter it's rather easy to think up of levels so long as you have a plot. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7d/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/7/7d/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/aid588593-v4-565px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":322,"bigWidth":"565","bigHeight":"395","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} If it's the former than it's a lot trickier since you have to think up of various themes to run through with 5-10 levels. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/3/31/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/aid588593-v4-565px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":322,"bigWidth":"565","bigHeight":"395","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Always make each level center around a single theme. For example if its covered in cemeteries and graveyard it's horror-themed and if it's taking place in a Himalaya-like place it's ice-themed. One of most frequently-used (and clever) themes is horror. Of course when it comes to horror make it Halloween-ish horror (the holiday) not Hellraiser-ish horror. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/8/83/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/aid588593-v4-565px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":322,"bigWidth":"565","bigHeight":"395","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} An absolute must for every non-linear game is a water-themed level. Try to introduce it early on such as Level 4 or Level 5 which is when the game should begin turning difficult. The point is to get the player more oriented to swimming (no matter how badly the controls handle) for later in the game. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/3/37/Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/aid588593-v4-565px-Make-a-Video-Game-Level-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":322,"bigWidth":"565","bigHeight":"395","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} When it comes to music think what would fit best. The Banjo-Kazooie series is ground-breaking in this regard since every level's music sounds exactly as it should. The level that consists of a polluted harbor is quirky and low-pitched whilst the level that consists of the 4 seasons each has a different music for each season: a cheery, chirpy song for spring, a slow violin tune for summer, an upbeat horn tune for fall and a harp-like tune with tambourines for winter. If you wish to have a boss have the boss fit with the theme of said level. If the level is themed to the Amazon rainforest have a tapir or sloth be the boss. Make sure that under any conditions you don't interchange it (e.g. in a water-themed level you have a desert lizard boss). How difficult it is should depend on how early and/or later in the game it is. If possible try to think up of a theme that has never been done before. Once more the Banjo-Kazooie series is a good example of this. For example beforehand no one had ever tried to make levels like a cargo-loading polluted harbor, the Mesozoic Era, or a forest in the four seasons of the year. Try to think outside the box. The kind of challenges should once again depend on the level's theme. If the level is wind-themed perhaps you need to get something out of a cloud without being set afire away by a strong wind.
